title: Ticket #3535: Fetching user priorities from negotiator takes a long time
description:
Resolved/abandoned as user priorities are now fetched from the collector

Fetching user priorities from negotiator takes a long time; at times it has appeared that the negotiator waits for the end of a (potentially long) negotiation cycle until responding to a request to fetch user priority information. The end result to the user is often condor_userprio or condor_q -analyze:priority commands take a really long time to respond, or on a busy pool could timeout.

SamF will investigate what is going on here and report back to ToddT, since ToddT's recollection is at least at one point in the past the negotiator invoked daemon core's ServiceCommandSocket() method periodically while doing negotiation specifically to avoid the above situation.

Please refrain from remarks/comments on this ticket for a few days until SamF's initial investigation is done. Thanks! -ToddT
remarks:
2013-Mar-21 14:01:12 by samf:
condor_userprio (or possibly condor_q -analyze:priority) takes a long time to run. We found that it hangs when the listening socket corresponding to the initial command socket (initial_command_socket or DC Command Handler) finds that there is an incoming command, spawns a new socket to read data, and then there is no data to read on the new socket. When there is data to read from the new socket, the data is read and the initial command finishes. In the case where the command hangs, the command DaemonCommandProtocol::WaitForSocketData gets called, the socket gets registered, and the socket is not listened to by the negotiator until after the end of the negotiation cycle; therefore, the command will not be run until after the end of a negotiation cycle. Currently, DaemonCore::ServiceCommandSocket does not listen to any socket other than the initial command socket. If the command for some reason does not finish, it will not finish until after the negotiation cycle.

I also have a design document that I will probably post soon.

2013-Mar-22 16:11:16 by samf:
I've attached a patch. Some differences from the design doc are that I need to call CallSocketHandler_worker instead of calling HandleReq directly. This will then call the handlers for a registered socket. Also, if the socket needs to be removed from sockTable, CallSocketHandler_worker will do that. One caveat is that I also need to make sure to exit the do/while loop in ServiceCommandSocket prematurely if the socket has been removed as otherwise an EXCEPT will be thrown unnecessarily.

2013-Mar-22 23:38:53 by bbockelm:
Hi,

Did you ever get the chance to attached the design doc?

Brian

2013-Mar-25 09:04:09 by samf:
How I reproduced the problem. First, I submitted a larger number (10000) jobs to make the negotiator take a long time.

Submit File: 

universe = vanilla
executable = /bin/sleep
getenv=true
arguments = 30

should_transfer_files = yes
when_to_transfer_output = on_exit_or_evict

output = o
error  = e
log    = l

+NEGOTIATE_ALL_JOBS_IN_CLUSTER = True

queue 10000

I think +NEGOTIATE_ALL_JOBS_IN_CLUSTER = True in the submit file didn't do the trick. So I changed my local condor config file. Settings that I have in my condor_config.local file: 

######################################################################
# Testing long times for fetching user priorities from negotiatior
######################################################################
NEGOTIATE_ALL_JOBS_IN_CLUSTER = True
NEG_SLEEP = 0
MAX_NEGOTIATOR_LOG = 1000000000
I needed to up the size of my negotiator log for debugging purposes. NEG_SLEEP can be set to a non-zero integer to have the negotiator sleep for that many seconds after each negotiation. I found that when NEG_SLEEP = 1 caused the problem to sometimes go away, so I did my testing with NEG_SLEEP = 0.

Initially, I just called condor_userprio many times from the command line. I did see that I would get codnor_userprio to hang doing this. This would happen during the negotiation cycle. When the cycle finished, condor_userprio would finish. In order to call condor_userprio more times and faster than I could do so manually, I created a shell script to call condor_userprio: 

#!/bin/sh
while true
do
    date +"%D %T:%N"
    condor_userprio
done
date will spit out the date and time with nanoseconds. I found I needed about 1/100th of a second resolution to distinguish clearly if condor_userprio was hanging.

I would pipe the result of this script into a file and examine the output of that file continuously to see the freeze.

Once the negotiation cycle finished, condor_userprio would not hanging again until another negotiation cycle started.

2013-Mar-25 09:28:18 by samf:
Two problems I ran into when implementing my solution:

  1. Making sure that I didn't do an infinite loop with the do/while loop in ServiceCommandSocket. HandleReq can return a result not equal to KEEP_STREAM. With the original code when HandleReq ran working on the socket that had been waiting for data, it would set its variable always_keep_stream to false. Since the stream is supposed to close in this case and we don't close it, the Selector for that stream will keep indicating that there is data to be read. Consequently, selector.has_ready() always returns true and we get an infinite loop. My initial work around was to reset the selector when HandleReq returned a value not equal to KEEP_STREAM. That would cause the loop to break.

  2. As indicated in the previous point, the steam/socket should be closed under some circumstances. To reduced code duplication and also to use the handlers associated with WaitForSocketData, I switched from HandleReq to DaemonCore::CallSocketHandler_worker which calls both HandleReq and CheckPrivState. It also calls Cancel_Socket appropriately. I just need to give CallSocketHandler_worker the correct parameters to emulate the original call to HandleReq. In the case where a socket has been cancelled, I need a way to exit the loop so that an EXCEPT is called (causing the negotiator to crash) when evaluating selector.failed(). We do expect a failure to occur when select is called while examining the recently closed socket. To exit the loop, I used the conditions that Register_Socket uses to check to see if a slot is empty or available; if those conditions returned ture, then I call selector.execute() to change the state of the selector to exit the loop.

2013-Apr-10 14:16:13 by tannenba:
Code Review

  1. Calling selector.execute() on a potentially undefined descriptor (or even worse, on a descriptor that has been reused) to break out of loop seems dangerous. Break out of the loop a different way, ie. use another variable.

  2. Doing a string compare on the handler.descrip as a string constant is not a great idea, since someone could change the descrip elsewhere in the code and surprisingly break something. Either make this string a constant defined in one place, or even better, add a data member to the sockTable entry that says if DC is waiting for data.

  3. Confirm that the socket is not waiting for an outgoing connect when deciding to select on it or not. I.e., make sure SockEnt is_connect_pending is false.

  4. Add a comment explaining why you are iterating with one socket being passed to select() vs placing lots of sockets into the select fd set and calling select once. Perhaps it is because the set of fds could change every time you call a handler?

  5. Why invoke CallSocketHandler_worker() vs CallSocketHandler() ? please place a comment telling future hackers why this choice was made. Perhaps because you want the handler to be called in this same thread?

  6. Add a knob (no need to document it) to disable ServiceCommandSocket() all together. By default, ServiceCommandSocket() should do its thing, but having this knob will give us a safety net in the field (since it is a bit dangerous thing at least until the Future Work happens).

Test Plan

Please confirm (via remarks with console captures in the ticket, or even better via regression test) by doing a before and after test for:

  1. Confirm condor_userprio waits until end of negotiation cycle before patch, and responds immediately after patch -- and negotiator continues to operate correctly afterwards :).

  2. Confirm that "condor_off -fast" waits until end of negotiation cycle before patch, and responds immediately after patch.

  3. Confirm that both issuing a "condor_reconfig" or sending a SIGHUP waits until end of negotiation cycle both before and after patch, because iirc RH added code to make this always true and we want to make sure we didn't muck that up.

Future Work

Would really like to see a list of daemon_core command ints passed to ServiceCommandSocket(). We know that it is unlikely for every command to be safe to be handled this way, so the idea is the caller pass an explicit whitelist of safe command ints. Probably would require adding a data member to the SockEnt which contains the command int (once it is discovered), and any socket with command that does not match the white list is simply registered and thus the handler is not invoked until going back to the main daemoncore driver loop.

2013-Apr-16 12:23:46 by samf:
Responding to the code review.

  1. Sounds reasonable. Using break command to exit loop.

  2. Had to make class DaemonCommandProtocol have friend class DaemonCore; (in theory). Then, adding to SockEnt the parameter bool waiting_for_data. This already will get initialized to false. We then set this to true in the function Register_Socket.

  3. Adding another condition on the non-initial command socket. Easy.

  4. The original code in ServiceCommandSocket has a do-while loop that selects on the initial command socket. There is a comment in the code that says, "loop until no more commands waiting on socket". While we are servicing a socket, more data could have come in and need to be read. So at least for the initial command socket, we need to call select multiple times. In such a case, we would need to confirm after each time we find that the selector is ready to ready data if the current socket we are examining is ready to be read by using selector.fd_ready(i,Selector::IO_READ) where i is the current socket index. We know that we will have to do this in the case where we have the initial command socket having a new command and another socket waiting for data. selector.has_ready() will return true. I do not see how this results in any fewer system calls. I also see this making the code harder to read because the loop will need to contain code to ask if the particular socket still has data to read.

  5. CallSocketHandler() when called on the initial command socket will perform an accept on the socket, which seems to be the desired behavior during the main DaemonCore loop. I don't think we want this behavior in ServiceCommandSocket and so we need to call the worker version. However, CallSocketHandler() does have a way to control the maximum number of accepts per cycle. 
    m_iMaxAcceptsPerCycle = param_integer("MAX_ACCEPTS_PER_CYCLE", 8);

  6. Added.

2013-Apr-16 15:14:09 by samf:
Code Review Remark:

Point 4: Actually, I DO expect the list of fds to change. When we call a command that had previously been waiting for socket data, the socket will be removed from the list of registered sockets. I then will be later on possibly still be performing select on that fd. In which case, to ensure that selector.execute() does not go into the FAILED state, I would need to remove the fd from the selector. In order to accommodate this and deal with the fact selector.fd_ready needs cannot accommodate a non ready state, I see more reason to iterate through each socket via the selector rather than use the fd_ready command. I cannot use FD_ISSET directly because I don't have access to the read filters, and nor do I want to be maintaining this filter either.

2013-Apr-16 15:56:43 by samf:
Regarding Future Work:

In the class DaemonCommandProtocol (defined in daemon_command.h), there are three integers in:

  1. m_req Comment says: the command that was sent
  2. m_real_cmd Comment says: for DC_AUTHENTICATE, the final command to execute
  3. m_auth_cmd Comment says: for DC_AUTHENTICATE, the command the security session will be used for

daemonCore->CommandNumToTableIndex(m_real_cmd,&cmd_index) is how we get the command integer. We could use the commnad daemonCore::InServiceCommandSocket to determine if we're in ServiceCommandSocket. To create a whitelist, this would be in daemonCore::HandleReq just before doProtocol gets called or somewhere in DaemonCommandProtocol::ExecCommand(). We'd ask if we were indeed in ServceCommandSocket and if the cmd_index was on our white list, then we'd continue on. Otherwise, ExecCommand() should return CommandProtocolInProgress.

It's not perfect, but it's a start down this path.

2013-Apr-16 16:39:38 by samf:
In terms of the test plan,

  1. condor_userprio can wait until the end of the negotiation cycle without the patch and does not wait with the patch. There is a knob that controls the implementation status of the patch.

  2. condor_off -fast seems to finish before the negotiation cycle finishes even without the patch. This is good, yes? I suspect there is some condition I'm not properly testing.

  3. condor_reconfig and sending a SIGHUP both indeed wait until the end of the negotiation cycle.

2013-Apr-16 18:39:59 by samf:
There's a lot more code to use when using multiple fds. Also, CallSocketHandler() actually seems to work, so we're using that now instead of CallSocketHandler_worker().

2013-May-10 10:54:27 by tannenba:
I noticed that v7.9.6 is now running on the UW CHTC central manager in beta testing, and condor_userprio still seems slow to respond; please investigate/explain. Thanks.

Also re test plan, I asked for "remarks with console captures in the ticket, or even better via regression test". I see a remark on the testing, but it does not include console captures showing the explicit config/commands used such that someone could reproduce the test - for an example of this see #3255 or #2905. When can this (or even better a regression test) happen?

2013-May-24 16:26:43 by samf:
I've confirmed that when used on the main CHTC pool, condor_userprio still takes a long time. Next week, I plan on figuring out why it takes so long using GDB.

2013-Jun-14 14:12:08 by samf:
I have had a lot of trouble attaching gdb to the condor_negotiator. What I do know is that on the cm, the negotiator enters ServceCommandSocket, creates a Selector::selector (because of the print statement associated with Selector::reset commamnd), and then exits via one of the following return statements. If it didn't exit, we would expect to see more print statements associated with the Selector::add_fd command.
